snippet: The family of a woman who died when her General Motors car crashed in 2003 was never told her death was linked to a flaw that has killed at least 12 others.
abstract: Unredacted copy of internal General Motors report on its failure to disclose deadly ignition switch defect in small cars shows that death of Jean P Averill in 2003 looms large in crisis that has engulfed GM; Averill, among 13 victims that GM's legal department linked to defect, was earliest such fatality company logged on its books; Averill's family, until informed by The New York Times, was not told of link by GM and did not know it was eligible to receive a minimum of $1 million from a victim's compensation fund the automaker established.

byline.contributor: Bill Vlasic contributed reporting from Detroit, and Rebecca R. Ruiz and Danielle Ivory from New York.

lead_paragraph: The family of a woman who died when her General Motors car crashed in 2003 was never told her death was linked to a flaw that has killed at least 12 others.

headline.main: 11 Years Later, Woman’s Death Is Tied to G.M. Ignition Defect
headline.print_headline: 11 Years Later, Death Is Tied to G.M. Defect
